thread.title: Google 'Punishes' Users Of Ad-Blocking Software

title: Google 'Punishes' Users Of Ad-Blocking Software
text:
Sponsored By Google 'Punishes' Users Of Ad-Blocking Software Some Google Chrome users report seeing YouTube adverts despite having blocking software installed - but a glitch is blamed. 12:03, UK, Tuesday 08 September 2015 Adverts are appearing on YouTube despite the use of ad-blocking software Share by email Google appears to be punishing users who install advert-blocking software by forcing them to sit through lengthy commercials with no option to skip them. 
Software such as AdBlock Plus is increasingly popular with users who don't want to see pop-ups, banner adverts and pre-roll advertising on videos. 
But this starves websites of advertising revenue, and it appears that Google is hitting back. 
Several Twitter users have reported being presented with lengthy adverts when viewing videos on Google-owned YouTube - with no option to skip them. 
The adverts appear despite ad-blocking programs being installed, meaning Google may have found a way to bypass the software. 
The issue has only been reported on Google's Chrome browser at the moment, and only some users have reported seeing adverts. 
One user posted a screengrab of a three-minute advert playing on YouTube which they could not skip. 
They wrote: "A three-minute ad? Really? I have AdBlock also how is this even possible?" 
Several Twitter users claimed that people were effectively being "punished" for using advert-blocking software. 
But Ben Williams, from AdBlock Plus, says the adverts only appeared because of an "issue in Chrome" which it expects Google to fix. 
Sky News has contacted Google for a comment.
